Abstract Abstract
This specification defines how an Atom Publishing Protocol collection This specification defines how an Atom Publishing Protocol collection
should process multipart/related requests and also defines how a may process multipart/related requests and also defines how a service
service announces that it accepts multipart/related entities. announces that it accepts multipart/related entities.
Editorial Note Editorial Note
To provide feedback on this Internet-Draft, join the Atom Protocol To provide feedback on this Internet-Draft, join the Atom Protocol
mailing list (http://www.imc.org/atom-protocol/) [1]. mailing list (http://www.imc.org/atom-protocol/) [1].

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
The Atom Publishing Protocol [RFC5023] defines Media Collections and The Atom Publishing Protocol [RFC5023] defines Media Collections and
how to create a Media Resource by POSTing the media to the Media how to create a Media Resource by POSTing the media to the Media
Collection. RFC 5023 does not define handling multipart/related Collection. RFC 5023 does not define handling multipart/related
[RFC2387] represenatations nor does it specify how the acceptance of [RFC2387] representations nor does it specify how the acceptance of
such representations should be advertised in the Service Document. such representations should be advertised in the Service Document.
This specification covers both the processing and the Service This specification covers both the processing and the Service
Document aspects of handling multipart/related content. Document aspects of handling multipart/related content.
1.1. Notational Conventions 1.1. Notational Conventions
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this
document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119]. document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119].
1.2. Design Considerations 1.2. Design Considerations
The primary objective of multipart/related POSTs is to reduce round- The primary objective of multipart/related POSTs is to reduce round-
trips for creating Media Resources. There will be three round trips trips for creating Media Resources. There are three round trips in
in the typical Media Resource creation scenario; POST of the media, the typical Media Resource creation scenario; POST of the media, GET
GET of the Media Link Entry, and subsequent PUT of the updated Media of the Media Link Entry, and subsequent PUT of the updated Media Link
Link Entry. This specification reduces that to just a single round- Entry. This specification reduces that to just a single round-trip
trip by allowing the client to package up the media and the by allowing the client to package up the media and the associated
associated Media Link Entry into a single multipart/related Media Link Entry into a single multipart/related representation which
representation which is POSTed to the Media Collection. is POSTed to the Media Collection.
The design of the handling of multipart/related representations was The design of the handling of multipart/related representations is
aimed at backward compatibility, that is for non-multipart/related aimed at backward compatibility, that is for non-multipart/related
aware clients to fully function. A second aim was to retain and aware clients to fully function. A second aim is to retain and
utilize the expressiveness of the current app:accept element in the utilize the expressiveness of the current app:accept element in the
Service Document. The last aim was to ease the burden on clients by Service Document. The last aim is to ease the burden on clients by
allowing the mulitpart representation to be constructed in an order allowing the multipart representation to be constructed in an order
that was convenient for the client. that is convenient for the client.
1.3. Applicability 1.3. Applicability
The applicability of multipart/related representations to AtomPub The applicability of multipart/related representations to AtomPub
Collections is restricted to just creating new entries in Media Collections is restricted to the creation of new entries in Media
collections. It does not specify the creation or use of a resource collections. It does not specify the creation or use of a resource
that supports a GET to return the multipart/related representation that supports a GET to return the multipart/related representation
nor does it specify the creation or use of a resource that supports a nor does it specify the creation or use of a resource that supports a
PUT of a multipart/related representation. PUT of a multipart/related representation.
2. Terminology 2. Terminology
The terms Collection, Media Resource, Media Link Entry, and Service The terms Collection, Media Resource, Media Link Entry, Foreign
Document are used as defined in [RFC5023]. Markup, and Service Document are used as defined in [RFC5023]. The
term Object Root is used as defined in [RFC2387].
3. Multipart Representations 3. Multipart Representations
This section covers the constraints on a multipart/related This section covers the constraints on a multipart/related
representation sent to a Media Collection. Section 5 covers how a representation sent to a Media Collection. Section 5 covers how a
client discovers that a Media Collection accepts multipart/related client discovers that a Media Collection accepts multipart/related
representations. representations.
This specification defines a format for multipart/related There may be other specifications that define uses for multipart
representations sent to a Media Collection. There may be other representations in the AtomPub context; this specification only
specifications that define formats for multipart representations, as describes one particular representation and how to use it in the
such this specification will only cover what constitutes a valid media-resource creation process. Follow-on multipart/related
representation for this specification. Follow-on multipart/related
specifications will have to define a method by which a server can specifications will have to define a method by which a server can
differentiate which specification is in force, which is beyond the differentiate which specification is in force, which is beyond the
scope of this document. scope of this document.
A multipart/related POST to a Media Collection MUST be a valid A multipart/related POST to a Media Collection MUST be a valid
multipart/related representation as defined by [RFC2387] and MUST multipart/related representation as defined by [RFC2387] and MUST
contain two body parts. One body part MUST be an Atom Entry with a contain two body parts. One, referred to as the Media Part, MUST be
media type of 'application/atom+xml' or 'application/ an Atom Entry with a media type of 'application/atom+xml' or
atom+xml;type=entry'. The other body part MUST be of a media type 'application/atom+xml;type=entry'. The other, referred to as the
acceptable to the collection. The object root MUST be the Media Link Media Part, MUST be of a media type acceptable to the collection.
Entry. The Media Link Entry atom:content element MUST have a 'src' The object root MUST be the Entry Part. The Entry Part's atom:
attribute whose value is the URI of the related media contained in content element MUST have a 'src' attribute whose value is the URI of
the compound object. The 'src' attribute value MUST be a 'cid:' URI the related media in the Media Part. The 'src' attribute value MUST
as defined by [RFC2392]. The Content-Type: header of the POST be a 'cid:' URI as defined by [RFC2392]. The Content-Type: header of
request MUST have a value of "application/atom+xml;type=entry" or the POST request MUST specify "application/atom+xml;type=entry" or
"application/atom+xml" for its required type parameter. "application/atom+xml".
4. Server Processing 4. Server Processing
A successful POST of a multipart/related representation to a Media A successful POST of a multipart/related representation to a Media
Collection proceeds as any successful Media Resource creation. The Collection causes several resource-creation processes to occur as
non-Atom object is used to create the Media Resource and the Atom described in [RFC5023]. The Media Part is used to create a Media
Entry object is used to create the Media Link Entry. Media Resource Resource as if it had been posted as a request body to the collection
creation proceeds as defined in Section 9.6 of [RFC5023] with a as described in section 9.6, and the Entry Part is used to create the
successful creation returning a 201 status code and a Location: corresponding Media Link Entry. Assuming these two steps are
header pointing to the newly created Media Link Entry. All other successful, the server returns a 201 status code and a Location:
aspects of [RFC5023] MUST be followed for Media Resource creation header pointing to the newly created Media Link Entry. The
including Slug: header processing. applicable rules from [RFC5023] MUST be followed, including Slug:
header processing.
While a multipart/related request replaces three round trips in the While a multipart/related request replaces three round trips in the
typical Media Resource creation scenario, AtomPub has no mechanism to typical Media Resource creation scenario, AtomPub has no mechanism to
report partial success and the handling of a multipart/related report partial success. Thus, the handling of a multipart/related
request by the server MUST be atomic; it should either succeed with a request by the server MUST be atomic; that is, either succeed with a
201 Created status code, or return an error status code. 201 Created status code, or return an error status code.
5. Service Document Extension 5. Service Document Extension
An AtomPub service announces that it will accept multipart/related An AtomPub service announces that it will accept multipart/related
POSTs by an extension to the app:accept element. The 'alternate' POSTs by an extension to the app:accept element. The "alternate"
attribute is a spaced separated list of tokens. The only token attribute's value MUST be one more more tokens, space-separated if
defined by this specification is "multipart-related". The presence more than one. The only token defined by this specification is
of the "multipart-related" token in the 'alternate' attribute "multipart-related". The presence of the "multipart-related" token
indicates that the collection accepts multipart/related POSTs for the in the 'alternate' attribute's value indicates that the collection
value of the app:accept element. The following example indicates a accepts multipart/related POSTs whose Media Part has a content-type
collection that allows the creation of resources with the Ogg matching that specified in the app:accept element. The following
Bitstream Format and will also accept them in multipart form. example indicates a collection that allows the creation of resources
with the Ogg Bitstream Format and will also accept them in multipart
form.
<app:accept alternate="multipart-related">application/ogg</app:accept> <app:accept alternate="multipart-related">application/ogg</app:accept>
The 'multipart' attribute is foreign markup and will be ignored by The 'multipart' attribute is foreign markup and will be ignored by
clients that do not understand multipart/related uploads. In clients that do not understand multipart/related uploads. In
addition it permits the full range of the app:accept element to be addition it permits the full range of the app:accept element to be
used. The following indicates that the collection accepts any image used. The following indicates that the collection accepts any image
media type and will also accept them in multipart form. media type and will also accept them in multipart form.
<app:accept alternate="multipart-related">image/*</app:accept> <app:accept alternate="multipart-related">image/*</app:accept>
The default is collections do not accept multipart/related
representations.
The 'alternate' attribute allows clients that are unaware of The 'alternate' attribute allows clients that are unaware of
multipart/related to continue to operate as normal since the multipart/related to continue to operate as normal since the
alternate attribute is foreign markup. The alternative, which was to alternate attribute is foreign markup. The alternative, which is to
put a multipart/related media type in the app:accept element loses put a multipart/related media type in the app:accept element, loses
flexibility since the 'type' parameter to the multipart/related media flexibility since the 'type' parameter to the multipart/related media
type accepts only media types and not media ranges. type accepts only media types and not media ranges.
6. Examples 6. Examples
Here is an example service document that contains two media Here is an example service document that contains two media
collections. The first collection accepts multipart/related POSTs collections. The first collection accepts multipart/related POSTs
for video media types only. The second collection accepts multipart/ for video media types only. The second collection accepts multipart/
related POSTs for image/jpeg and image/png media types. related POSTs for image/jpeg and image/png media types.
